contents.title: @hippopedoid on Twitter
contents.description_html: “We took all (21M) English abstracts from PubMed, used a BERT model (PubMedBERT) to transform them into 768D vectors, and then used t-SNE to visualize them in 2D. We used the 2D map to explore the library, and confirmed each insight in 768D. We focus on four insights. 2/n”
contents.description: “We took all (21M) English abstracts from PubMed, used a BERT model (PubMedBERT) to transform them into 768D vectors, and then used t-SNE to visualize them in 2D. We used the 2D map to explore the library, and confirmed each insight in 768D. We focus on four insights. 2/n”

contents.title: How Black Cartographers Put Racism on the Map
contents.generated_title: How Black Cartographers Put Racism on the Map
contents.description_html: Op-ed: The Black Panthers are just one chapter in a long history of “counter-mapping” by African Americans.
contents.description: Op-ed: The Black Panthers are just one chapter in a long history of “counter-mapping” by African Americans.

source.title: How Black Cartographers Put Racism on the Map

contents.content_html: Cartography is a form of activism. Through the process of counter-mapping, populations excluded from political decision-making use maps and geographic data to visualize and communicate information about inequality.
contents.content: Cartography is a form of activism. Through the process of counter-mapping, populations excluded from political decision-making use maps and geographic data to visualize  and communicate information about inequality.

Through the process of counter-mapping, populations excluded from political decision-making use maps and geographic data to visualize and communicate information about inequality. Click here for more: https://t.co/8da64UEGmw @NextCityOrg" / Twitter

contents.title: Tweet by @shamshi_adad
contents.content_html:
Marina
@shamshi_adad

I love wikipedia’s map of places where Bach lived. All other information is irrelevant, we don’t need to know when he lived in these places, in what order, or what surrounded them — history isn’t real, cartography isn’t real, only thing that exists is Bach’s peregrinations.

![https://pbs.twimg.com/media/ENR4SxTWkAAxEqN.jpg](https://pbs.twimg.com/media/ENR4SxTWkAAxEqN.jpg)

Jan 2, 2020, 1:24:55 PM
contents.description_html: I love wikipedia’s map of places where Bach lived. All other information is irrelevant, we don’t need to know when he lived in these places, in what order, or what surrounded them — history isn’t real, cartography isn’t real, only thing that exists is Bach’s peregrinations.

contents.content_html: I'm being honest, I really do love this map! Not all maps need to be scrupulously accurate, I think the best thing a map can be is thought-provoking, causing you to look at space in a new way.

wikipedia places where bach lived - Google Search

contents.content_html: If we can build an interface to LMs that let humans directly guide and manipulate the conceptual “path” a model takes when generating words, it would create a feedback loop much tighter and more engaging than the prompt-wait-retry cycle we’re used to today. It may also give us a new way to think about language models. Rather than “text-completion”, language models may be able to become tools for humans to explore and map out interesting latent spaces of ideas.
contents.content: If we can build an interface to LMs that let humans directly guide and manipulate the conceptual “path” a model takes when generating words, it would create a feedback loop much tighter and more engaging than the prompt-wait-retry cycle we’re used to today. It may also give us a new way to think about language models. Rather than “text-completion”, language models may be able to become tools for humans to explore and map out interesting latent spaces of ideas.

source.title: Imagining better interfaces to language models | thesephist.com
A GPS for the mind | thesephist.com

contents.title: Navigate, don’t search | thesephist.com
contents.description_html: Humans are bad at coming up with search queries. Humans are good at incrementally narrowing down options with a series of filters, and pointing where they want to go next. This seems obvious, but we keep building interfaces for finding information that look more like Google Search and less like a ma…

contents.content_html:
Recently, I’ve been thinking about maps as tools for artistic creation and exploration. Transformative map-making as a creative goal. I’m not talking about the kind of map that traces a coastline. Maps, in this context, is just a way of making connections.

Digital biophilia has been an anchor point in my generative explorations. I incorporate the idea of nature, rocks, plants, fields, life, and landscapes, but I try to not think in terms of representations/replicas of the real counterparts. Instead, I want to derive new maps, explore new ways of seeing and contextualizing well-known natural elements. Virtual landscapes that don’t try to emulate the real world.

I believe the idea of “true forms” is ingrained in us. The idea that things (objects, processes, structures) should be a certain way, or be used in a certain way. That it’s possible to deviate from “the correct”. Getting away from this too. Should be no secret that I’ve been thinking about Deleuze.

I haven’t read Deleuze. I’ve only been exposed through memes, drunk discussions with friends, and short youtube videos. My view of his philosophy might be riddled with misconceptions. This doesn’t matter to me. I enjoy the fragments this mythological meme creature has expressed. There’s no true form of a philosophy either—simplified derivations of incomprehensible ideas might be more valuable to me anyway. This way of engaging might even be in line with a Deleuzean mode of thought. I just want to play, bathe in culture, and make up something new.

Most days, I don’t consider these things very deeply. I’m writing this confusing text to sort out vague ideas and form a feedback loop: I’d like to think more about these things and how they relate to my art and life, so I write, try to mull a bit, and keep tinkering, on repeat. Trying to make art like maps: connect fragments, combine ideas, process old works. Guess this is true (and even obvious) for many, but consciously typing these words enforces this way of thinking, and makes a little sense of it.
contents.content:
Recently, I’ve been thinking about maps as tools for artistic creation and exploration. Transformative map-making as a creative goal. I’m not talking about the kind of map that traces a coastline. Maps, in this context, is just a way of making connections.

Digital biophilia has been an anchor point in my generative explorations. I incorporate the idea of nature, rocks, plants, fields, life, and landscapes, but I try to not think in terms of representations/replicas of the real counterparts. Instead, I want to derive new maps, explore new ways of seeing and contextualizing well-known natural elements. Virtual landscapes that don’t try to emulate the real world.

I believe the idea of “true forms” is ingrained in us. The idea that things (objects, processes, structures) should be a certain way, or be used in a certain way. That it’s possible to deviate from “the correct”. Getting away from this too. Should be no secret that I’ve been thinking about Deleuze.

I haven’t read Deleuze. I’ve only been exposed through memes, drunk discussions with friends, and short youtube videos. My view of his philosophy might be riddled with misconceptions. This doesn’t matter to me. I enjoy the fragments this mythological meme creature has expressed. There’s no true form of a philosophy either—simplified derivations of incomprehensible ideas might be more valuable to me anyway. This way of engaging might even be in line with a Deleuzean mode of thought. I just want to play, bathe in culture, and make up something new.

Most days, I don’t consider these things very deeply. I’m writing this confusing text to sort out vague ideas and form a feedback loop: I’d like to think more about these things and how they relate to my art and life, so I write, try to mull a bit, and keep tinkering, on repeat. Trying to make art like maps: connect fragments, combine ideas, process old works. Guess this is true (and even obvious) for many, but consciously typing these words enforces this way of thinking, and makes a little sense of it.
